is a |-separated list of option names. It should be listed in shortest-to-longest order, e.g. h|help. may contain a specifier following one of the |-separated entries, and a value separator list following the specifier.

The property is initialized based on whether a = or : follows one of the aliases within . = specifies a value, while : specifies an value. If neither = nor : is not specified, then is used. The value specifier may be used anywhere within , so n|name=, n=|name and n=|name= are equivalent, but you cannot mix types; n:|name= is invalid.

A default handler may be specified by using <> as the option name. The default handler is invoked for any unhandled argument within ; consequently, if a default handler is provided then
will return an empty .

The default handler may either be provided as a stand-alone , in which case it may not specify a other than . Alternatively, it may be an alias, in which case the must accept an or value, and must be 1.

Multiple values may be bundled together, such as -opt key=value. The value separator list specifies which characters can be used to split the value argument to generate separate values. The value separator list is available when is greater than 1, and and an was specified. The value separator list follows the = or : and is one of the following:

term.para: A sequence of character enclosed by { and }. Multiple such sequences may be specified by listing the {...} sequence multiple times.

The sequence {} requires that each value be a different argument, and no argument splitting will be performed. This sequence has no effect if other separators are also listed (as separate arguments are always permitted for
values).

item.term: Any literal character other than { and }.

remarks.para: If the separator list is not provided, then =: is the default separator list.

For example, the prototype "A:+-*/" would permit any of `+', `-', `*', or `/' to be used to split an argument into values, so -A:5/2 would generate the sequence of values 5 and 2 for the option -A. Furthermore, the prototype "A={-->}{=>}" would permit either the string --> or the string => to be used, so -A A->B C woud parse A->B as one value and C as the other value, while -A A-->B C would parse A as one value and B as the other value while C would be unhandled (unless the option required 3 values, in which case C would be the 3rd value).

member.name: T:NDesk.Options.OptionSet
member.summary: A class to parse program options.

remarks.para:
A common requirement for command-line programs is option parsing. The command line consists of a sequence of .
parses this argument sequence, invoking actions of registered s when a sequence of arguments matching the s requirements are encountered. 's are registered with and its overloads.
, returns a of all arguments which were not matched by a registered .
Three conditions must be met for a sequence of arguments to be considered as a match for an :

item.term:
The must be matched. An has one or more names, as returned from . Matched names must start with a (even though the flag is not part of the ): -, --, or /. There are several different name matching algorithms:
names are matched when the argument consists solely of a flag followed by an option name.
Examples: -opt, --opt, and /opt are all simple names for the opt option.
names are matched when the argument consists of a flag, followed by an option name, followed by + or -. If a + follows the name, the option is enabled, otherwise the option is disabled.
Examples: -opt+ and -opt- enable and disble the opt option.
names are matched when the argument consists of a flag, followed by an option name, followed by a = or :, followed by an (optional) string.
Examples: -opt=A, --opt:B, and /opt=C all provide a value for the opt option.
names are matched only when simple, boolean, and assigned names are not matched, the flag is -, and the first character matches a registered option. Any number of (single-character) boolean options may be bundled in this fashion, and at most one or option (which will use all remaining characters within the argument as a value).
Examples: -xvfinput-file could match the boolean s x and v and the value-accepting option f, which will get the value input-file. (Other interpretations are also possible, depending upon which options are registered.)
As a fallback, a may be registered which will handle arguments which are not handled by any of the above matching algorithms. The default handler is designated by the name <> (which may be an alias for another named ).
Default handlers are useful for argument runs -- sequences of arguments that are not related to each other but are instead related to a prior option on the command line, and it isn't desirable to use named options for these. For example, mdoc-assemble --format=ecma DirA DirB --format=man FileC would process DirA and DirB with --format=ecma in effect, and then process FileC with --format=man in effect.
See
for additional details regarding default option handlers.
The must be matched. specifies the option's type. See below for more information.

The must be matched. Whether an option takes any values is dependent upon the option's type (previous bullet), but the number of values the option either accepts or requires is specified by the property.

remarks.para: There are three types of s that can be parsed:

item.term: Boolean options, which correspond to a value of . When a matching argument is encountered, their registered action is invoked immediately. The value will be non- if the value is true, e.g. if -option or -option+ is specified, and the value will be if the value is false, e.g. if -option- is specified.

term.para: Optional value options, which correspond to a value of . Optional value options are not "greedy"; they will only get their value only from the current argument. If the value is not present, is provided to their corresponding .
Thus, -opt:value would pass value to the action registered for opt, while -opt value would pass to the action registered for opt and value would be an unparsed argument.

Required value options, which correspond to a value of . Required value options are "greedy" -- if the value is not found within the current argument, the following argument(s) will be used to supply the value(s). Once enough values have been parsed, their corresponding is invoked.
Thus, both -opt:value and -opt value would pass value to the action registered for opt.
If no value can be found, an is thrown from .

block.para: Use of OptionSet is split up into two parts:

item.term: Initialization.
Parsing.

block.para: During the phase, new instances are created and associated with an action to perform when the Option requirements are met (e.g. when a required value has been encountered). This phase is not thread safe. All options added during this phase are considered to have been .
There are three ways to add s to the :

item.term: With C# collection initializers, as used above.

Explicitly by calling
and the other Add overloads.
By creating a new subclass of and adding it via . This is not recommended, but is available if you require more direct option handling than the default implementation provides.

block.para:
During the phase, an
is enumerated, looking for arguments which match a registered option, and invoking the corresponding action when an option and associated (optional) value is encountered. During this phase, the instance itself is thread safe, but full thread safety depends upon thread-safety of the registered actions. Any option-like strings for names that haven't been registered, e.g. --this-was-never-registered=false, and all arguments that are not used as option values are returned from
or processed by the default handler <>, if registered.
Subclasses can override the following methods to customize option parsing behavior:

example.para: The following example demonstrates some simple usage of .
The output (under the influence of different command-line arguments) is:
example.code:
$ mono greet.exe --help Usage: greet [OPTIONS]+ message Greet a list of individuals with an optional message. If no message is specified, a generic greeting is used.
Options: -n, --name=NAME the NAME of someone to greet. -r, --repeat=TIMES the number of TIMES to repeat the greeting. this must be an integer. -v increase debug message verbosity -h, --help show this message and exit
$ mono greet.exe -v- -n A -name=B --name=C /name D -nE Hello A! Hello B! Hello C! Hello D! Hello E!
$ mono greet.exe -v -n E custom greeting for: {0} # Using new message: custom greeting for: {0} custom greeting for: E
$ mono greet.exe -r 3 -n A Hello A! Hello A! Hello A!
$ mono greet.exe -r not-an-int greet: Could not convert string `not-an-int' to type Int32 for option `-r'. Try `greet --help' for more information.
example.para: Notice how the output produced by --help uses the descriptions provided during OptionSet initialization. Notice that the requiring a value (n|name=) can use multiple different forms of invocation, including: -n value, -n=value, -name value, -name=value, --name value, --name=value, /name value, and /name=value.

Notice also that the boolean v option can take three separate forms: -v and -v+, which both enable the option, and -v-, which disables the option. (The second greet invocation uses -v-, which is why no debug messages are shown.)
Finally, note that the action can specify a type to use. If no type is provided, the action parameter will be a . If a type is provided, then will be used to convert a string to the specified type.
The following example shows how options and values can be bundled together.
The output (under the influence of different command-line arguments) is:
example.code:
$ mono bundling.exe --help Usage: bundling [OPTIONS]+ Demo program to show the effects of bundling options and their values
Options: -D[=VALUE1:VALUE2] Predefine a macro with an (optional) value. -d=VALUE1-->VALUE2 Alternate macro syntax. -o=VALUE Specify the output file -f=VALUE The input file -x Extract the file -c Create the file -t List the file --color[=VALUE] control whether and when color is used -h, --help show this message and exit
$ mono bundling.exe -D bundling: Missing macro name for option -D. Try `greet --help' for more information.
$ mono bundling.exe -DA -DB=C "-dD-->E" "-dF=>G" -d "H=>I" -cf input --color -ooutput Macros: A=<null> B=C D=E F=G H=I Options: Input File: input Ouptut File: output Create: True Extract: False List: False Color: <null>
$ mono bundling.exe -cfv input def handler: color=; arg=input Macros: Options: Input File: v Ouptut File: Create: True Extract: False List: False Color: <null>
$ mono bundling.exe -xctf input Macros: Options: Input File: input Ouptut File: Create: True Extract: True List: True Color: <null>
$ mono bundling.exe --color=auto -o output -finput Macros: Options: Input File: input Ouptut File: output Create: False Extract: False List: False Color: auto
$ mono bundling.exe --color=on A B --color=off C D def handler: color=on; arg=A def handler: color=on; arg=B def handler: color=off; arg=C def handler: color=off; arg=D Macros: Options: Input File: Ouptut File: Create: False Extract: False List: False Color: off

example.para: The following example shows a custom OptionSet subclass with the following additional functionality:

item.term: Option name lookup is done in a case insensitive fashion, so --name and --NAME are identical.
Option-like strings cannot be used as values to options, so --name --repeat is an error.
A key/value parser is provided, to show the use of custom and subclasses.

example.para: The output (under the influence of different command-line arguments) is:
example.code:
$ mono subclass.exe -n A -Name=B --NAME=C /nAMe D Hello A! Hello B! Hello C! Hello D!
$ mono subclass.exe --Repeat -name A
$ mono subclass.exe -Name --Repeat 3 subclass: Found option `--Repeat' as value for option `-name'.
$ mono subclass.exe --Map a b -mAp c=d /maP=e=f Key: a=b Key: c=d Key: e=f
$ mono subclass.exe --map 'a\' 'b\' c 'd\' 'e\' f Key: a\b\c=d\e\f

item.term: That --name is treated in a case-insensitive fashion.
That repeat has an optional value, so with --Repeat -name A the default int value is passed (0), so no message is printed.
That name has a required value, so -Name --Repeat 3 generates an error.
The DemoOptionSet.Add() method provides appropriate key/value option pairs to the callback method.

member.name: T:NDesk.Options.OptionValueType
member.summary: Specifies whether or not a takes a value, and if it does, whether it's optional or required.

summary.para: If an option takes no value, then the callback function will receive if the value is (e.g. -optionName- was used) and non- if the value is (e.g. -optionName, -optionName+).
This is specified by providing : after the option name within .
If a value is optional, the callback function will receive value if no value is provided, and will otherwise receive a non- value.
Options with optional values are not "greedy" -- the value must be part of the current argument, e.g. -opt:foo will pass "foo" as the value to -opt, but -opt foo will pass as the value to -opt.
This is specified by providing = after the option name within .

Options with required values are "greedy" -- if the current argument does not contain a value, the next argument will be used as the value, e.g. both -opt:foo and -opt foo will pass "foo" as the value to -opt.
